title: Thursday, 24th May, 2018
bodyHTML:
11:06 am

BE11:08am

Pseudonym @Shinshin You have to get in at 11...

AAAA Bonjour les amis !
11:10 am
BE11:10am

For those joining us late .... This is all pinned on the fact that Mr Musk's been wedgied, or tall poppied if you prefer. And he doesn't much like it, so is heading into the "screw you, you're all against me" mode.

RST Mornin'
BE11:11am

https://twitter.com/elonmusk/status/999364333674024960

BE11:11am

https://twitter.com/elonmusk/status/999367582271422464

BE11:11am

.... Pravda?

BE11:12am

Is this like a double irony? A double bluff? Is he saying it's actually a bad idea to have the public choose the news by popular vote? Because all you'd get is crowdsourced propaganda.

BE11:12am

Or is he genuinely proposing open peer review for news? Then had a few characters to spare so figured "Pravda" might be a funny way to use them?

red only need to look at his unstable private life
11:12 am
BE11:13am

Because there's already a media company called Pravda. Two, in fact.

Manxish Problem with this is that 'the public' are - by and large - idiots

And I'm guessing he'd mind quite a bit if I started a car company and called it Tesla. But perhaps I'm missing the subtleties of the joke.

CS1 @Manxish: And we trust them with the vote!
The Bernard Morning!
Pseudonym There was a boat company that called itself Jaguar in the '70s.. I think they won against Jaguar cars.
red death by distraction. misses deadline after deadline but throws a bone out to take the heat off

Anyway. We should probably move on from Musk, because this is the best take and we won't top it.

FTSE flatlining, having come off quite a bit yesterday.

Blackbag99 Is this like a double irony? A double bluff? Is he saying it's actually a bad idea to have the public choose the news by popular vote? Because all you'd get is crowdsourced propaganda. Have you seen the UK's media. It is 80% crowdsourced clickbait

11:20 am

You'll have seen Arash's story overnight: https://www.ft.com...-9334-2218e7146b04

BE11:21am

A trio of leading shareholders in Ireland’s Smurfit Kappa have demanded that Europe’s largest cardboard box maker end its refusal to engage with International Paper and enter into negotiations with the US group that has offered nearly €9bn to buy it.

The intervention by investors including Janus Henderson, the fund management group which is Smurfit’s third-biggest shareholder with a 4.3 per cent stake, comes as the Irish Takeover Panel has set a deadline of June 6 for IP to make a binding bid.

Pharma What I want is a browser plug-in that detects Twitter quotes and hides them. Some of the "news" stories would become blank pages.
Snail's pace Looks like some fun over at the DB AGM....
BE11:21am

“The message to Smurfit is to please either engage and get around the table with IP or give us reasons why you are not engaging,” said John Bennett, head of European equities at Janus Henderson told the Financial Times.

Soundbuy Missed that........
11:22 am
BE11:22am

That's the way to do it. If you want management to listen to your opinions, do it on the damn record. More of that, less of the "a top ten shareholder" stuff.

Blank canvas Tate & Lyle shrugging off US woes? any insights from either side of the page?
BE11:23am

So anyway, €40 a share is the buyside target cited in there. We're €34.7 live.

red crowdsource the new bitcoin. but it seems its an acceotable way for folks to take on high risk and lose money.
BE11:25am

Which is strategic value for box tech, right? You're already paying 7.5x EV/EBITDA for Smurfit at current price, which looks pretty toppy given the cyclicality and the exposure to dull stuff like containerboard prices.

11:25 am
BE11:25am

Here's Goldman Sachs to tell you about the acquisition.

BE11:25am

Reparenco operates two paper assets in the Netherlands with a total capacity of 675kt (405kt testliner and 270kt graphic with potential for testliner conversion) as well as a 750kt recovered fiber operation. Smurfit expects 2018 EBITDA of €72 mn for Reparenco, which would imply a pre-synergy multiple of 6.4x. On a trailing 12m basis, the multiple would be 11.2x; however, Reparenco was ramping up an asset during this period.
This acquisition is in line with the medium-term strategy announced by Smurfit earlier this year as it further expands and integrates into containerboard

Flaneur on Tesla - and I dont hold any shares or particularly give a stuff - the UK motoring press are very positive on the new mass market model 3 vehicle. I did not expect that.
BE11:26am

And that's all I have there.

11:26 am
undefined

Tate? Okay, Tate.

red lets see him deliver the car first
Tate & Lyle PLC (TATE:LSE): Last: 654.00, up 45 (+7.39%), High: 657.40, Low: 606.00, Volume: 2.33m
red as for his comments of the awd version handling better than an m3...sometimes better to keep your trap shut rather than open it and confirm your stupidity
11:27 am
BE11:27am

Decent numbers, decent outlook, sensible sounding review from the new CEO.

Coppy thanks for commenting on skg
red but again more defection and distraction, the awd version is twice as expensive. no longer a $35k car.
Electric Dragon Old Soviet joke: Izvestia means "news". Pravda means "truth". This is because in Izvestia there is no truth, and in Pravda there is no news.
BE11:28am

Headline numbers beat but it's bulk performance, mostly.

BE11:29am

Investec can summarise.

RST @Electric DragonBrilliant!!!
11:29 am
BE11:30am

Tate has reported FY18 PBTEA of £301m, in line with Vuma consensus of £299m. Adj. EPS of 50.1p is marginally ahead of
the 49.0p consensus. SFI EBIT of £192m is in line with consensus of £192m, while Bulk EBIT of £166m is better than
consensus of £158m, helped by strong sales of commodities (£24m higher y-o-y). The dividend is raised 2.5% to 28.7p for
the FY and net debt has fallen to £392m. The outlook statement is typically cautious, and calls for low single-digit constant
FX EPS growth (given higher energy and transport costs and a tough comparative in Commodities from FY18). We expect
consensus FY19 EPS forecasts to rise by around 3-5%, assuming £/$ will be a low single-digit drag on earnings, using
current rates. The tax rate is guided to 20-22%, compared with the 23.5% we model currently. Beyond FY19, guidance
targets gradually accelerating EPS growth.

BE11:30am

Rather smaller upgrade than others are pushing through.

Tom Dalgleish For the moment Musk does walk on water
Pharma @Flaneur perhaps when the only way you can get a test drive is to fly to California, or buy one for $$$ off employees, writing "what a c**p car" is unlikely to get your expenses bill signed off.
BE11:31am

Such as SocGen, which says:

11:30 am
BE11:31am

the group is guiding to 4-5% constant currency growth in FY19 Adjusted EPS, which we estimate could trigger c. 10% upgrades to current consensus

BE11:32am

And back to Investec for the Mr Hampton's strategy update.

BE11:32am

(1) a new divisional structure: Primary Products, Food & Beverage Solutions and Sucralose; (2) $100m of productivity savings over the next 4 years and (3) an acceleration in portfolio development through innovation, partnerships and acquisitions.

11:32 am
BE11:32am

We have argued that M&A needs to accelerate in order to diversify Tate’s product lines and customer base.
We view today’s statement as broadly supportive of this policy [...]. We note that the new CEO has already committed himself to a leverage ratio of 1-2x net debt/EBITDA, which will somewhat constrain the type of deals the company will be able to execute.

BE11:33am

Is that enough about corn wet milling? For the general reader, probably.

undefined
Blank canvas Thanks for Tate
11:33 am
BE11:34am

And I guess we should stop in at CapCo as well.

Capital & Counties Properties PLC (CAPC:LSE): Last: 302.30, up 6.6 (+2.23%), High: 303.00, Low: 290.00, Volume: 6.20m
BE11:34am

A stock that's been receiving an unusual amount of attention from every punter in the market for about six months now.

11:35 am
BE11:35am

Today, we get news that wasn't quite what was expected.

BE11:35am

The Board of Capital & Counties Properties PLC ("Capco") announces it is considering a demerger, which would result in two separately-listed businesses based around its prime central London estates, each with its own distinct investment prospects:

- Covent Garden, the world-class destination in the heart of central London, independently valued at over £2.5 billion at 31 December 2017, to be launched as an independent, prime central London retail-focused REIT, led by Ian Hawksworth

- a London development company centred around the Earls Court masterplan, which represents one of the most important large scale strategic opportunity areas in central London, led by Gary Yardley. Capco's share of property interests at Earls Court was independently valued at £759 million at 31 December 2017 (adjusted for the sale of The Empress State Building).

Electric Dragon @RST it belongs to a set of jokes called "Radio Yerevan jokes" https://johnkutensky.wordpress.com/2014/08/22/radio-yerevan-jokes/
Sails @red, re unstable, a man who divorces Talullah Riley *twice* definitely needs his head examining
BE11:36am

Chairman resigns as well.

11:36 am
BE11:36am

"whilst he is fully supportive of the Board's decision to consider a demerger" .....

Pharma @sails, without knowing the person, it may be that the insane thing was to marry her twice.
Sails @Pharma, hmm possibly
BE11:37am

So, the background here is that punters Bandit4 through Bandit10 and beyond have been talking since the back of last year about some kind of consortium offer for CapCo.

red clearly he doesnt learn his lessons.
BE11:38am

Involving existing shareholders, housebuilders, Saudis, all sorts. The makeup changed week to week.

FATDAZ Belated good morning
red and its this scatter cannon unstable approach that he brings to tesla
11:39 am
BE11:39am

That process might still be alive, I guess, assuming it ever was. Though if we take account the many months of rumourtrage, today's news looks a lot like a Plan B.

FATDAZ re Covent garden surely thats worth more than £2.5 bln ???
BE11:40am

And the value release from the Plan B is far from certain.

Mouselet in which case feel free to buy the shares in the REIT
BE11:40am

Here's Mike Prew at Jefferies.

red the way it is now, the company is not self sustaining. they are unable to jump from niche to mass mkt AND make a profit.
11:40 am
BE11:40am

It’s the (proposed) parting of the ways for these two completely separate businesses that should never have been conjoined. It’s difficult to see how this divorce adds any value and the hot money expecting a bid (Saudi SWF Olayan or Berkeley Group has both been mentioned in the press) will be disappointed. Earls Court as a stand-alone business could look distinctly over-valued, where the see-saw effect of writing-up Covent Garden as the interests in the 70 acres at Earls Court get written down (a process we do not think has hit fair value yet) could leave the development business poorly financed and needing a partner to boost liquidity and prove the valuation of c.£35m per developable acre we estimate (but stress testing this we can get down to £20m/acre).

FATDAZ @mouselet think I might look into that
BE11:41am

Covent Garden is valued at £2.5bn at Dec, but at a nose bleed cap rate of 2.1% on aggressive rental growth assumptions from £58.9m passing to an all-in ERV of £104.8m and an optimistic management target of £125m by 2020, and the sell-off in SHB yesterday post the interims doesn’t bode well. Since Soumen Das resigned (July 2016) as CAPC head of Financial Strategy and MD of Covent Garden to join SGRO as CFO, CEO Ian Hawksworth has aligned himself with Covent Garden and will now seek to head an independent, prime central London retail-focused REIT. CIO Gary Yardley, who has delivered the planning gains, gets his own train set and is the operational head of the London development company centred on the Earls Court masterplan. CAPC's share of the interests at Earls Court were valued at £759m (adjusted for the sale of The Empress State Building).

BE11:41am

Liberum, same conclusion.

11:41 am
BE11:41am

If you generously applied Shaftesbury’s trading multiple to CapCo’s Covent Garden estate we believe it would imply the market is applying a 38% discount to its Earls Court land value. We are not convinced that the parts are worth more than the sum. CapCo’s shares trade on a CY18E P/NAV of 0.87x in line with the sector 0.88x.

Mouselet Musk announced that they would make a loss on every lowest-spec car sold at $35k, and so would only sell cars at the $49k and above specs
red yet he took half a million $1k deposits for a $35k car
BE11:42am

[T]he Covent Garden estate has consistently grown and is valued at ~£2.5bn, accounting for ~75% of the combined portfolio. The West End has been unique in its resilience through cycles and we believe prospects remain excellent. However, given CapCo's achieved rents in Covent Garden we inevitably see a lower long-term level of sustainable growth than recent history.

Mouselet and when you reach the front of the queue you are told only a $49k car is available, or you can take your $1k and get to the back of the queue
BE11:43am

Peel Hunt, similar.

Mouselet This strikes me as somewhat on the grey side of financial engineering
red he did raise billions on that soundbite though. and thats what its all about. the next soundbite to raise cash to fill in the holes for the last project.
Mouselet Yes, he is managing to launch rockets; but Eike Battista did manage to pump oil, and it still fell apart
11:44 am
BE11:44am

 The majority of debt would likely be retained against Covent Garden given EC has negligible income. Against the £2.5bn Covent Garden valuation, this would equate to a LTV of 29% (reasonable) and would give a NAV of c£1.85bn. We assume this would trade at around NAV (broadly in line with Shaftesbury), giving a market cap of £1.85bn.
 At Earls Court, the property is valued at £980m and we believe this would trade on a discount given the weak prime residential market and the lack of income. Assuming say a 25% discount would mean a market cap of c£730m.
 So sum of the parts, we get back to c£2.6bn versus the current market cap of £2.5bn. So a small c3% gain before costs.

red of course u cannot short it as it will keep going up with the mkt and timing its demise while mkts are bullish is almost impossible. but there will come a day when the mkt decides enough is enough.
Mouselet What *is* the state of the London prime residential market? Is it nowadays purely a store of value for fleeing Chinese capital?
red its may take offerings from the europeans and asians to kick it off.
BE11:46am

There's an argument to make, I guess, that the demerger announcement is effectively putting a deadline to potential bidders for one, other, or both sides of the business.

BE11:47am

Meaning the punters aren't Scorchedfingers. Yet.

They consider the operating performance here to be in line with expectations. The gradual insurance mix change continued, with a 10% increase in general insured patients but excluding Linde (which is 70% general insured) the growth in general insured patients would have been 3%

Shore's selling pre results, FWIW.

BE11:55am

AO World’s (AO) results for the year to end of March 2018 are due on Tuesday 5th June. When AO last reported as part of its FY2018F post close trading update the company guided that group adjusted EBITDA loss was expected to fall within the range of £1.4m to £9.7m. Shore Capital is looking for an EBITDA loss in FY2018F of £5.4m. Importantly, we hope that the pre-close trading update in April is the beginning of the company developing a stronger track record of delivering City forecasts year-in year-out. We still have concerns about the level of losses in Germany and the Netherlands and continue to highlight that the company should crack these markets first, before considering further investment in any new territories (e.g. France). We remain concerned that the cost base remains too high, relative to the revenue line and we reiterate our SELL rating.

11:58 am
BE11:58am

The April rebound in retail sales retraced the weather induced fall in March. The breakdown shows broad based improvement across all main categories, particularly in petrol sales (+4.7% in April following -7% in March). Although this data is notoriously volatile, it is the first post “Beast from the East” print of hard data, and further upside surprises to activity data could lead to a repricing of market expectations of the timing of the next rate hike.

Tom Dalgleish @Fat, exactly. So few engineers in politics.
BE11:58am

his is, however, a notoriously volatile data series and the ONS highlights that combining March and April relative to the same period the previous year shows a general slowdown to growth at 1.3% from 2.9% for March and April 2017. Credit card expenditure data had signalled a rebound in April following weakness in March; however, it also continue to signal deceleration in annual growth rates across a broad range of categories. Furthermore, the BoE Agents’ summary of business conditions in May confirmed weakness in Q1, but also signalled further deterioration in the score for the value of retail sales turnover
